title-group.article-title: Novel hybrid acid–base membranes based on sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone), tetraethoxysilane and (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane for fuel cell application

abstract.p: Two kinds of novel hybrid membranes with and without (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (KH550) were produced using tetraethoxysilane dispersed in sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone) (SPAES) matrix by the sol–gel method. The obtained hybrid membranes (SPAES-K-SiO2 and SPAES–SiO2) possessed higher water uptake, proton conductivities and selectivity compared with the pristine SPAES membrane when the SiO2 content was 3 and 6 wt%, whereas the same properties of the obtained hybrid membranes decreased when the SiO2 content was 10 wt%. In addition, the acid–base interactions between SPAES and SiO2 could improve the dispersion of the inorganic particles (SiO2) in the SPAES matrix. As a result, SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membranes presented better methanol permeability and selectivity than SPAES–SiO2 hybrid membranes without the acid–base interactions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Many countries around the world are working to accelerate the development of hydrogen and fuel cell technologies to improve their energy, environmental security and economic security. Recently, there has been great interest in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) due to their high energy conversion efficiency and absence of pollutant emission. 1 –3 At present, the perfluorosulfonated membranes represented by Nafion® are competitive for use in PEMFC systems. However, they suffer from poor conductivity at relative low humidity and high temperature, high methanol permeability and high cost of materials. Therefore, it is necessary for direct methanol fuel cell to prepare a low-cost membrane with low methanol permeability and high proton conductivity.

Among the potential alternatives, sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone) (SPAES) is a promising material due to its high thermal stability, excellent mechanical strength, cost competitiveness and strong resistance to fuel cross-over for fuel cells. 2,4
–7 However, such sulfonated membranes must possess a minimum ion exchange capacity (IEC) of 1.4–1.7 meq/g so as to obtain the low ionic resistance that is required in the application of electromembranes. Although a high IEC is considerably beneficial to PEMFC applications, it readily sacrifices the mechanical property, dimensional stability and methanol permeation of the membrane materials 8 because of excessive swelling. However, at a low degree of sulfonation, the hydrophilicity of the polymer is too weak to attain adequate proton conductivity values. Therefore, numerous approaches, such as acid–base interactions, 9
–12 organic–inorganic hybrids13–19 and cross-linking, 20 –22 have been taken to improve the dimensional stability, water retention capacity and proton conductivity of membrane materials without sacrificing methanol permeation. Generally speaking, the interactions between acid and base polymers in hybrid membranes, such as ionic cross-linking (electrostatic forces) and hydrogen-bonding bridges, contribute markedly to control the swelling and methanol permeation of hybrid membranes. It is worth noting that the introduction of inorganic components into organic membranes by the sol–gel method can enhance water uptake and proton conductivity. 10 However, the synthesis of the base polymer is complex and costly. Luckily, the coupling agent KH550 containing amino groups can replace the base polymer containing amino groups. In addition, KH550 is cheaper and commercially available compared with the base polymer containing amino groups. Therefore, it may be introduced into SPAES instead of the base polymers, which not only results in the reinforced interfacial interaction between SPAES chains and silica nanoparticles but also improves the dispersion of inorganic particles in the matrix. More importantly, the process of membrane preparation is easier. Therefore, an alternative route that combines the interaction of acid–base polymers with organic–inorganic hybrids can effectively overcome the disadvantages of traditional PEMFC.

In this study, two kinds of organic–inorganic hybrid membranes, with and without the interaction of acid–base ionic pairs, were prepared by the sol–gel method. When KH550 and tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) were blended with SPAES, the acid–base interaction between the organic component (SPAES) and the silane coupling agent (KH550) prevented silica (SiO2) from agglomerating and formed the flexible membranes. The effects of acid–base interactions and the introduction of inorganic particles were discussed in detail. The properties related to fuel cell applications, such as proton conductivity, water uptake and methanol permeability, were thoroughly evaluated. Furthermore, the influence of KH550 on the properties of the membrane was investigated in comparison with hybrid membranes without KH550.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: 4,4′-Dichlorodiphenylsulfone (DCDPS) was supplied by Liyang Xingda Chemical Co., Ltd (China), and dried under vacuum at 120°C for 24 h prior to use. 4,4′-Dihydroxybiphenyl (BP) was purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co., (England, UK) and dried under vacuum at 60°C for 24 h. According to the literature, 3,3′-disulfonated 4,4′-dichlorodiphenylsulfone (SDCDPS) was synthesized through direct sulfonation using fuming sulfuric acid (H2SO4; ACS reagent 50% as free SO3, Beijing Chemical Reagent, China). 23 Tetramethylenesulfone (Beijing Chemical Reagent) was purified by vacuum distillation prior to use. Potassium carbonate (K2CO3; Beijing Chemical Reagent) was ground into fine powder and dried at 120°C for 24 h before use. KH550, TEOS, N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc, 99.8%), H2SO4 (95–98%) and toluene were obtained from Beijing Chemical Reagent. All the other reagents were commercially available and used without further purification.

sec.title: Synthesis of SPAES
sec.p: SPAES (IEC = 1.72) was synthesized as described in the existing literature, 24,25 through polycondensation of DCDPS (6 mmol, 3.45 g), SDCDPS (4 mmol, 3.93 g) and BP (10 mmol, 3.72 g) via nucleophilic aromatic substitution.

sec.title: Preparation of SPAES–SiO2 and SPAES-K-SiO2 hybrid membranes
sec.p: First, the dried SPAES powder was dissolved in DMAc to form a 10 wt% homogeneous solution. Then, KH550 and TEOS at a ratio of 1:4 (mol/mol) or TEOS alone was added to the above solution. In addition, the pH value of the mixed solution was adjusted to 4.0 by adding 0.1 M hydrochloric acid (HCl). The mixture was stirred for 12 h at room temperature, poured onto a clean glass plate, dried at 60°C for 12 h and then further dried at 80°C for 12 h and at 120°C for 12 h. The membrane was obtained after final drying at 120°C for 24 h in a vacuum oven. The hybrid membrane was converted to the required acid form by immersion in 2 M H2SO4 solution at 80°C for 3 h, followed by treatment with boiling deionized water several times to remove the residual free H2SO4 molecules in the acidified membrane. The SiO2 content of the mixture varied (0, 3, 6 and 10 wt%) based on SPAES, and the hybrid membranes with and without KH550 were denoted as SPAES–K–SiO2-x and SPAES–SiO2-x, respectively, where x was the weight percentage of SiO2 in the SPAES matrix. The thickness of the hybrid membranes was in the range of 70–90 μm.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were measured on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet Co., USA).

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was employed to assess the thermal stability of the membranes using a TGA Q500 thermal analyzer (TA Co., USA). Before analysis, the films were dried and kept in the TGA furnace at 120°C for 10 min. The samples were then heated to 800°C at 10°C min−1 in the air.
The cross-section morphologies of the membranes were examined with a scanning electron microscope (SSX-550, Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with energy dispersive x-ray (EDX) spectroscopy.

sec.title: Proton conductivity
sec.p:
The proton conductivity was measured with a four-electrode alternate current (AC) impedance method at 0.1 Hz–100 kHz, 10 mV AC perturbation and 0.0 V direct current rest voltage using a Princeton Applied Research Model 273A Potentiostat (Model 5210 frequency response detector, EG&G PARC, Princeton, New Jersey, USA). The membranes were cut into 1 cm width and 6 cm length and were fixed in a measuring cell with two outer gold wires to feed current to the sample and two inner gold wires to measure the voltage drops. All the membranes were mounted between two polytetrafluoroethylene plates. The cell was immersed in water during measurement. Before measurement, the films were hydrated in water for 24 h. sec.p:

Methanol solutions (10 mol L−1) were placed on one side of the cell and pure water was placed on the other side. Magnetic stirrers were used continuously during the measurement. The methanol concentration in the water cell was periodically determined using a GC-14C gas chromatograph (SHTMADU, Tokyo, Japan). sec.title: Preparation of SPAES–SiO2 and SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membranes
sec.p:
All the hybrid membranes with KH550 were transparent and flexible even when the theoretical content of SiO2 was up to 10 wt%. However, the hybrid membrane without KH550 was translucent when the SiO2 content was 10 wt%. This could be ascribed to the acid–base interactions between the sulfonic acid groups of SPAES 13
,26 and the amino groups of KH550, as described in Figure 1. Charge matching between the inorganic component (NH3 + groups) and the organic component (SO3 − groups) contributed to ionic cross-linking and further improved the dispersion of the inorganic particles (SiO2) in the SPAES matrix, followed by the enhancement of transparency.

caption.p: Preparation of SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membranes. SPAES: sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone); K: coupling agent KH550; SiO2: silica.

sec.title: FTIR spectroscopy
sec.p: Figure 2 shows the FTIR spectra of pure SPAES, SPAES–SiO2 and SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membranes. The strong characteristic peaks at 1029 and 1103 cm−1 were assigned to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of the sulfonic acid groups, respectively. Therefore, it could be concluded that the sulfonic acid groups were successfully introduced into the copolymers. The broad peak at around 3455 cm−1 indicated that there were a significant number of –OH groups in the hybrid membrane due to the noncondensed Si–OH and –OH stretching vibrations of the absorbed water. Compared with the FTIR spectrum of the pure SPAES membrane, two new bands at 461 and 957 cm−1 corresponding to the Si–O–Si bending vibration and the Si–OH stretching vibration appeared. The band at 3455 cm−1 of the SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membrane was broader than that of the pure SPAES membrane and the SPAES–SiO2 hybrid membrane, which might be ascribed to the acid–base interaction between the sulfonic acid groups in acid-form and amino groups in the KH550; these bands were substituted by the broad band of the N–H3 + vibration in the H+ form of hybrid membranes. 9 The peak at 2933 cm−1 in Figure 2(c) was assigned to the C–H stretching vibration of methylene groups, which also indicated that KH550 was successfully introduced into the hybrid membrane. The change in the peak position of the S=O stretching vibration observed in FTIR spectra could serve as an evidence of the ionic interaction between SPAES and KH550; however, it was difficult to observe the shift in the S=O peak due to some overlap from strong Si–O stretching vibration bands located at about 1100 cm−1. Nevertheless, the peak became broader when compared with the pristine membrane, which validated the existence of inorganic particles. 16,26

caption.p: FTIR spectra of pure SPAES (a), SPAES–SiO2 (b) and SPAES–K–SiO2 (c) hybrid membranes. FTIR: Fourier-transform infrared; SPAES: sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone); K: coupling agent KH550; SiO2: silica.

sec.title: Thermal property
sec.p: The thermal stability of the pure SPAES and the SPAES−K−SiO2 hybrid membranes was investigated by TGA under air atmosphere. Membrane samples for TGA analysis were preheated to 120°C under air atmosphere and held isothermally for 10 min to remove the residual water and solvents. As shown in Figure 3, all the hybrid membranes exhibited similar two-step degradation. The first weight loss started at around 310°C, which was associated with the loss of the sulfonic acid groups. This degradation temperature shifted to lower temperatures with increasing SiO2 loading, which was ascribed to the decomposition of the organic silane of KH550. 18 In the second weight loss region, the polymer residues were further degraded at around 520°C, which corresponded to the decomposition of the main chain of polymer. The second weight loss temperature shifted toward high temperatures with the increase in SiO2 content because of the formation of the SiO2 network. The weight residues of the hybrid membranes containing SiO2 were higher than that of the unfilled SPAES membrane. In summary, the introduction of SiO2 did not damage the thermal stability of the membranes.

caption.p: TGA cures of pure SPAES and SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membranes. TGA: thermogravimetric analysis; K: coupling agent KH550; SiO2: silica; SPAES: sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone).

sec.title: Membrane morphology
sec.p: The hybrid membranes with and without KH550 were prepared by the sol–gel method. Figure 4(a) to (e) shows the cross-sectional morphologies of the pristine SPAES membrane and the hybrid membranes. Compared with the SPAES membrane, SiO2 particles could be seen in the cross-sections of all the hybrid membranes without obvious aggregation. The presence of SiO2 particles was also confirmed by the EDX spectra, as shown in Figure 4(f1) and (f2), from which it can be seen that the cross-sections of the SPAES–SiO2-x hybrid membranes are rougher than those of the SPAES–K–SiO2-x membranes; this is especially obvious in the SPAES–SiO2-10% membrane. The cross-sections of the hybrid membranes with KH550 are almost as smooth as that of the pure SPAES membrane. This suggested that better compatibility existed between the organic and the inorganic components and that KH550 improved the homogeneity of the hybrid membranes, which was ascribed to the acid–base interaction between sulfonic acid groups and amino groups in the KH550. The interaction between the sulfonic acid groups of SPAES and the amino groups of KH550 would affect the water uptake, proton conductivity and methanol permeability of the hybrid membranes, besides their surface morphology.

caption.p: Cross-sectional SEM images of (a) pure SPAES, (b) SPAES–SiO2-3, (c) SPAES–K–SiO2-3, (d) SPAES–SiO2-10 and (e) SPAES–K–SiO2-10 with different magnifications and EDX Si-mapping on the cross-sections of (f1) SPAES–K–SiO2-3 and (f2) SPAES–K–SiO2-10 hybrid membranes. Red indicated silica. EDX: energy-dispersive x-ray; SEM: scanning electron microscopy; K: coupling agent KH550; SiO2: silica; SPAES: sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone).

sec.title: Water uptake
sec.p: Water is necessary for the conduction of protons in proton exchange membranes (PEMs). 27 The greater the water uptake of the membrane, the larger the proton conductivity will be. As can be seen in Table 1, the water uptake values in both the SPAES–SiO2 and the SPAES–K–SiO2 systems increase with the increase in SiO2 content, whereas the water uptake values begin to decrease when the SiO2 content goes up to 10 wt%. This might be ascribed to the hygroscopic Si–OH group increasing the content of bound water 28 and to nano-sized SiO2 particles having large specific surface areas, which induce higher water uptake of hybrid membranes compared with that of the pure SPAES membrane. However, when the SiO2 content was in excess, such as up to 10 wt%, –SO3H groups were diluted, and the decreased IEC became the primary factor in water uptake compared with the hygroscopic effect of SiO2. As shown in Figure 5, the SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membranes had lower water uptake than the SPAES–SiO2 hybrid membranes with the same SiO2 content and at the same temperature, due to the increased interaction between the SPAES and the SiO2 inorganic network in the presence of KH550.

caption.p: Water uptake of SPAES–SiO2 and SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membranes with different SiO2 contents at 80°C. SPAES: sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone); K: coupling agent KH550; SiO2: silica.
IEC, water uptake, proton conductivity and methanol permeability of the hybrid membranes.

fn.p: IEC: ion exchange capacity; SPAES: sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone); K: coupling agent KH550; SiO2: silica.

sec.title: Proton conductivities
sec.p:
Figures 6 and 7 show the proton conductivities of the SPAES–SiO2 and SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membranes at different temperatures, respectively. At the same temperature, the proton conductivities of the hybrid membranes increased with the increasing SiO2 content in the range of 0–6 wt%, which was consistent with the water uptake as mentioned above. The proton conductivity was influenced by three key factors: the IEC, the water uptake of the membranes and the microscopic structure between the inorganic component and the polymer. The reduction in the IEC was mainly attributed to the dilution effect of SiO2 on the sulfonic acid groups but did not sacrifice the conductivities of the hybrid membranes. This conclusion was in accordance with the results previously reported in the literatures. 29
–32 The decrease in the IEC was compensated by the increase in silanol moieties, which was helpful in increasing the water uptake and therefore contributed to enhancing the proton conductivity. The positively charged –Si–OH groups in the acidic medium perhaps also endowed the SiO2 particles with proton conduction capability. As a result, the proton conductivities of the hybrid membranes were improved. In addition, the SiO2 particles in the hybrid membranes widened the average interchain distance of SPAES and facilitated the transportation of hydrated ions and methanol. 32 The larger SiO2 content blocked the hydrophilic pathways and suppressed the transmission channel of proton; this was validated by the decrease in the proton conductivities of the SPAES–SiO2-10% and SPAES–K–SiO2-10% membranes. As listed in Table 1, the IEC values of the hybrid membranes are lower than that of the pristine membrane and are reduced to 1.55 meq/g when the SiO2 content was 10 wt%. Therefore, the proton conductivity was determined by the number of sulfonic groups.

caption.p: Proton conductivities of SPAES–SiO2 hybrid membranes at different temperatures. SPAES: sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone); SiO2: silica.
Proton conductivities of SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membranes at different temperatures. SPAES: sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone); K: coupling agent KH550; SiO2: silica.

sec.p: Figure 8 shows the proton conductivities of the SPAES–SiO2 and SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membranes in liquid water at 80°C. The hybrid membranes with KH550 had lower permeability values than the hybrid membranes without KH550 at the same SiO2 content and temperature; this was due to the electrostatic interaction between the amino groups of KH550 and the sulfonic acid groups of SPAES. Such an ionic cross-linking structure in the hydrophilic ion cluster region and the ion channels of SPAES would greatly block the transportation of both protons and methanol molecules. 33 Therefore, the strong interaction decreased the availability of protons transportation and resulted in the reduction of proton conductivity.

caption.p: Proton conductivities of SPAES–SiO2 and SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membranes with different SiO2 contents at 80°C. SPAES: sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone); K: coupling agent KH550; SiO2: silica.

sec.title: Methanol permeability and selectivity
sec.p: In DMFCs, the PEMs are an effective barrier to prevent methanol diffusion from the anode to the cathode, which will lead to low fuel efficiency. Accordingly, the methanol permeability coefficients of hybrid membranes with and without KH550 as well as Nafion 117 membrane were measured at room temperature. Figure 9 displays the methanol permeability coefficients for the SPAES–SiO2 and SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membranes as well as Nafion 117 membrane. It could be obviously seen that all the hybrid membranes, including pure SPAES membrane, exhibited lower methanol permeability compared with Nafion 117. More importantly, the methanol permeability of the hybrid membranes with KH550 was lower than that of the membranes without KH550. This indicated that the introduced ionic cross-linking structure based on the acid–base interaction helped control the methanol crossover in the SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membrane. Furthermore, the values of methanol permeability increased when the SiO2 content was 3 and 6 wt%, whereas decreased when the SiO2 content was 10 wt%. It was concluded that methanol was transported by diffusion in the membrane and convection with water. 34 Therefore, the variation in methanol permeability was similar to that of water uptake. SiO2 physically resulted in the obstructive interaction between SPAES chains. Consequently, the average interchain distance of SPAES increased, resulting in high water uptake and low methanol barrier properties. However, when the SiO2 content was in excess, the water uptake decreased, followed by a reduction in proton and methanol transportation. The microstructure of the SPAES-based materials might be changed during the formation of SPAES–SiO2 or SPAES–K–SiO2 membranes to induce the above results, and the aggregated SiO2 particles hindered the penetration of methanol molecules.

caption.p: Methanol permeability of SPAES–SiO2 and SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membranes with different SiO2 content and of Nafion 117 at 20°C. SPAES: sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone); K: coupling agent KH550; SiO2: silica.

sec.p: As a crucial part of DMFCs, the electrolyte membranes need to have high proton conductivity and low methanol permeability. The potential performance of DMFC membranes is often evaluated in terms of selectivity, which is defined as the ratio of proton conductivity to methanol permeability. Higher selectivity is necessary to achieve better membrane performance. The selectivity values of the hybrid membranes investigated in this work are shown in Figure 10. It was found that the selectivity of the hybrid membranes increased when the SiO2 content was 3 and 6 wt% but decreased when the SiO2 content was 10 wt%. In addition, the SPAES-K–SiO2 membranes were clearly superior to the SPAES–SiO2 membranes in selectivity. In particular, the SPAES–K–SiO2-6% membrane possessed the best selectivity. The results suggested that the incorporation of SiO2 into SPAES membranes via KH550 and TEOS and the interaction of acid–base pairs could improve the performance of the membranes.

caption.p: The selectivity of the SPAES–SiO2 and SPAES–K–SiO2 hybrid membranes. SPAES: sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone); K: coupling agent KH550; SiO2: silica.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, two kinds of SPAES and SiO2 hybrid membranes with and without KH550 were successfully prepared. The ionic pair interaction improved the compatibility between the organic (SPAES) and inorganic (SiO2) components, leading to the homogeneous dispersion of SiO2 in the SPAES matrix. At the same time, the acid–base interaction between KH550 and SPAES also restricted polymer chain mobility and increased the interaction between the polymer and the SiO2 inorganic network structure. These findings suggest that the strong interaction decreased the availability of proton transportation and resulted in the reduction of proton conductivity, but the change was slightly little. It is worth noting that the introduced ionic cross-linking structure based on the acid–base interaction increased the interaction between polymer chains and helped control the methanol crossover. Furthermore, nano-sized SiO2 particles had large specific surface areas, which induced higher water uptake in the hybrid membranes than in the pure SPAES membrane, leading to an achievement of higher proton conductivity. The SiO2 particles in the hybrid membranes widened the average interchain distance of the SPAES chains and facilitated the transportation of hydrated ions and methanol. However, the water uptake, proton conductivity, methanol permeability and selectivity were all reduced when the SiO2 content reached 10 wt%. Thus, we can state that the incorporation of SiO2 into SPAES membranes via KH550 and TEOS containing acid–base interactions has a potential application in DMFCs.
